docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Israel Presses Retaliation In West Bank and Gaza Israeli warplanes and helicopters bombarded Palestinian security offices in eight areas of the West Bank and Gaza Strip -- including the compound of Yasir Arafat, where he was said to have been at work. Israeli officials said they had no intention of harming Mr. Arafat and that their goal was to compel him to act by threatening his hold on power. At least two Palestinians were killed and scores were injured. The attacks began after three suicide bombings over the weekend killed 25 people. A1 The Bush administration questioned whether Mr. Arafat was capable of leading the Palestinian people and dropped its calls for Israel to use restraint. Officials denied that the United States had given Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel any go-ahead to eliminate Mr. Arafat as a legitimate political leader. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: House and Senate negotiators have begun serious discussions on a compromise that would broaden health insurance coverage for workers with mental illness while limiting the cost to employers. But senior House Republicans and business groups are staunchly opposed to the deal. The compromise would outlaw disparities in coverage between mental and physical illness under group health plans sponsored by employers with more than 50 workers.
docs.abstract: House and Senate negotiators discuss compromise to broaden health insurance coverage for workers with mental illness while limiting cost to employers; compromise would bar disparities in coverage between mental and physical illness under group health plans sponsored by employers with over 50 workers; would grant exemption to employers that could show coverage would raise insurance costs by over certain amount; employers of all sizes lobby against proposal; Rep Nancy L Johnson backs proposal (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cindy Brody, my sister-in-law, was only 40 when she realized that something bad was happening to her ability to hear. Telephone conversations were a challenge and there were lots of misunderstandings even during one-on-one conversations, including those with her husband at the dinner table. But the day of reckoning came when she heard a riding instructor say ''to hell with her'' about a disabled woman who wanted to ride a horse, when in fact the man had said ''I'm helping her.''
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on dealing with hearing loss, one of most prevalent chronic health conditions in United States; notes some 20 million people with serious hearing deficits fail to use hearing aids; quiz to help in recognizing hearing loss (M)d

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 5,000 machinists at Pratt & Whitney walked off the job today here and at three other plants in Connecticut, after rejecting a contract proposal that they say offered increased pay but not job security. It is the first strike of this magnitude in more than 40 years at Pratt, which makes half of the jet engines in the Western world. The 5,100-member union began the strike just after midnight, following approval of a walkout on Sunday afternoon by nearly 70 percent of the 4,040 union members who voted.

headline.main: 5,000 Jet-Engine Machinists End Talks and Begin a Strike

docs.abstract: More than 5,000 machinists at Pratt & Whitney walk off job in East Hartford, Conn, and three other plants after rejecting contract proposal that offers increased pay but not job security; no new negotiations are scheduled (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A New Jersey judge sent four schoolteachers to jail today for disobeying a return-to-work order, the first time in more than two decades that striking teachers in the state have been incarcerated. Judge Clarkson S. Fisher Jr. of State Superior Court ordered the four to remain in the Monmouth County jail for at least one week, unless they decide before then to return to their classrooms in the sprawling central New Jersey suburb of Middletown Township.

headline.main: New Jersey Teachers Jailed for Continuing to Strike

docs.abstract: New Jersey Superior Court Judge Clarkson S Fisher Jr orders four striking teachers in Middletown, NJ, to go to jail for disobeying return-to-work order; says he has no other way to compel strikers to comply with order issued on first day of walkout; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The federal policy of increasing payments to health maintenance organizations in the hope of persuading them to stay in the Medicare program has largely been a failure, federal investigators said today. The investigators, from the General Accounting Office, said that H.M.O.'s had continued to leave Medicare and that very few had returned to the program, despite the higher payments.

headline.main: H.M.O.'s Flee Medicare Despite Rise In Payments

docs.abstract: General Accounting Office investigators say that federal policy of increasing payments to health maintenance orgns in hope of persuading them to stay in Medicare program has largely been a failure; say that HMO's continued to leave Medicare and that very few had returned to program, despite higher payments; some health maintenance orgns say they will stay in Medicare next year, but are planning very large increases in premiums, co-payments and other fees; about 5.6 million people, or 14 percent of 40 million Medicare beneficiaries, are in HMO's (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Carrying boxes packed hastily in the few minutes before police escorts started shepherding them into elevators, about 4,000 employees who had been summarily dismissed from the Enron Corporation streamed out of the company's two sparkling office buildings here today. Shortly before 11 a.m., managers told almost every employee in the company's headquarters to go home, sit by the telephone and wait for a call that would tell them if they still had a job.

headline.main: Sent Home To Sit and Wait By the Phone

docs.abstract: About 4,000 Enron Corp employees are summarily dismissed and escorted by police from company's two Houston office buildings; confusion reigns over their employment status; mounted police disperse throngs of exiting workers (M) y

docs.lead_paragraph: Matt Heard is alive. That transparent fact never struck him as remarkable in itself. As Mr. Heard put it, ''I've always been alive.''

headline.main: Alive and Well, No Matter What the Lists Say

docs.abstract: Many people believed missing in September 11 terrorist attacks are turning up alive; names cropped up on victims' lists and were duplicated without ever being verified; tales of people like Matt Heard, who was away on vacation but whose picture was posted at Union Square in lower Manhattan, explains why early estimates of those who died have turned out to be off target; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Matt Heard is alive.    That transparent fact never struck him as remarkable in itself. As Mr. Heard put it, ''I've always been alive.''
docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''All in Police Dept. Face Counseling'' (front page, Nov. 30): While the New York City Police Department recognizes the major mental health implications of Sept. 11, millions of Americans seeking treatment will discover that their health plans hinder rather than help them receive treatment. Patients often pay far more out of pocket for mental health care than for physical care; plans frequently cover fewer days in a hospital and fewer outpatient visits.
docs.abstract: Reps Patrick J Kennedy and Marge Roukema letter on Nov 30 article on counseling for New York City police officers in wake of Sept 11 attacks urges House leaders to accept Senate-passed measure to ensure parity between mental and physical health coverage

docs.lead_paragraph: The Ford Motor Company will announce plans later this week to slash 401(k) and health benefits for its salaried workers as part of an effort to overhaul its cost structure and return to profitability. Salaried workers will no longer receive one of the bull market's most coveted benefits, their 401(k) matching contributions. Ford had offered its salaried workers matching benefits of 60 cents for every dollar contributed to their 401(k) plans, for up to 10 percent of their salary.

headline.main: Ford to Cut Retirement Benefits And Insurance for Some Workers

docs.abstract: Ford Motor Co to cut 401(k) retirement plan matching benefits and health benefits for salaried workers as part of effort to cut costs and return to profitability; will suspend shift at Edison, NJ, plant and lay off about 600 hourly workers (M)4
